Name: El Salvador Finca Nombre de Dios Honey
Review: Stone fruit, dark chocolate and sweet florals characterize this all-Bourbon coffee from a woman-owned farm in El Salvador.

Name: Ethiopia Gera Limmu Oromia
Review: A bright and zesty, floral- and spice-driven wet-processed Ethiopia cup.
Coffee Origin: Limu Woreda, Oromia region, southwest Ethiopia

Name: Kenya Kabare Konyu
Review: A classic Kenya cup, juicy-sweet, with leading notes of black currant backed up by cocoa and spicy florals.

Name: Costa Rica Francisco Ruiz
Review: A roundly sweet-tart Costa Rica honey-processed cup with pretty notes of stonefruit and molasses, framed by aromatic wood notes.
Coffee Origin: Sabanilla de Alajuela, Central Valley, Costa Rica

Name: Alemu Bukato Espresso
Review: A nuanced, richly layered Yirgacheffe espresso with bold fruit and floral tones complicated by hints of fine musk throughout both the straight shot and in milk.

Name: Alemu Bukato Ethiopia
Review: A classic washed Yirgacheffe cup: juicy and crisply sweet-tart with notes of stone fruit, citrus blossom and chocolate throughout.

Name: ASOPEP Colombia
Review: A sweet, chocolaty FTO Colombia cup with umami intrigue.

Name: Tarime Tanzania
Review: A bright, engaging, complex Tanzania coffee. Inviting notes of dried tropical fruit and rich florals bookend sweet herb notes and a vanilla-like suggestion reminiscent of fresh cigar wrapper.

Name: Guachepelin Costa Rica
Review: A crisply elegant expression of red honey-processed coffee by a masterful producer in Costa Rica.
Coffee Origin: Sabanilla de Alajuela, Central Valley, Costa Rica

Name: Berlina Geisha
Review: A soaring Gesha cup: balanced, both delicate and rich, deeply floral and stone fruit-laden.

Name: Gatugi Triple
Review: A confident Kenya with a classic cup profile: bright, juicy, with prominent fruit and floral tones grounded by a resonant current of umami.

Name: Sulawesi Toarco
Review: A chocolaty coffee animated by rich nut and floral tones.
Coffee Origin: Toraja growing region, south-central Sulawesi, Indonesia

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Natural Espresso
Review: A rich-toned natural-processed Yirgacheffe espresso, saturated with complex fruit notes balanced by delicate honeysuckle-like flowers and fragrant aromatic wood.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Natural
Review: A fruit-and-chocolate-saturated natural-processed Yirgacheffe, lush and syrupy. For lovers of fine ports and fruit-bomb California red table wines. Casual coffee drinkers who assume all coffees taste about the same should try this one.

Name: Guatemala Finca El General Lot ALT8 Espresso
Review: A single-origin espresso that invokes the tropics, with plumeria-like flowers and sweetly tart fruit notes akin to tamarind.

Name: Green Dolphin Blend Espresso
Review: A sophisticated espresso blend, rich and chocolaty, with notes of elegant flowers and deeply sweet dried fruit.

Name: H Coffee Espresso Blend 01
Review: A fine chocolate-driven espresso blend with supporting notes of sweet florals and smoky aromatic cedar.

Name: Brazil Conquista
Review: A chocolaty Brazil cup with sweet nut notes throughout, animated by dried stonefruit and floral suggestions.

Name: Ethiopia Kochere Natural
Review: An accessible natural-processed Ethiopia cup, slightly darker-roasted than is typical, with notes of tropical fruit and a pleasing brandy-like ferment.

Name: Via Instant Veranda Blend Blonde
Review: We enjoyed the caramel, nut and cocoa and the relative cleanness of the cup, though a salt-toned wood lurked.

Name: KANU Colombia Mild Roast Americano (Instant Coffee)
Review: An ultra-dark French roast in instant format that manages to maintain some hints of flavor, while avoiding the sullen burned-building character of many dark- or ultra-dark-roasted instants.

Name: Augie‚Äôs Ethiopia Layo Teraga Natural (Instant Coffee)
Review: The juicy, lushly sweet-tart character of a fine natural-processed Ethiopia largely makes it through the rigors of solubilizing in this top-of-the-line instant coffee.
Coffee Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, southern Ethiopia

Name: Premium Coffee (Instant Coffee)
Review: At 20 cents per serving, inexpensive. Not much else positive to say about it.

Name: Augie‚Äôs Ethiopia Layo Teraga Washed (Instant Coffee)
Review: Rewards patience, which should reveal, beneath the fresh-cut wood, the crisp, sweet grace and complex aromatics of a fine washed Ethiopia.
Coffee Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, southern Ethiopia

Name: Taster‚Äôs Choice House Blend (Instant Coffee)
Review: Not a pleasant experience.

Name: Coava Costa Rica Los Nacientes (Instant Coffee)
Review: A creditable effort to deliver the clean, classic character of a high-grown Costa Rica in instant format.

Name: Ethiopia Duromina (Instant Coffee)
Review: Quietly lively washed Ethiopia that preserves some of the lemony citrus, cocoa and perfumy sandalwood of this treasured type in instant coffee format.

Name: Kochere Yirgacheffe Ethiopia (Instant Coffee)
Review: An instant that captures some of the zesty, lemon-and-cocoa character of a good Yirgacheffe, with a subtle whiff of flowers and sandalwood as well.

Name: Rayos del Sol Peru Light Roast (Instant Coffee)
Review: The balanced grace of Peru is sustained in this instant coffee. The cocoa notes are particularly pleasing, the hints of salty wood less so.

Name: The Blend Sumiyaki Coffee (Instant Coffee)
Review: An unapologetic darker roasted instant coffee in the smoky Japanese style.

Name: Via Instant Colombia Medium Roast (Instant Coffee)
Review: Not much survives the dark roast and the solubilizing, and what does is not particularly pleasing.

Name: Finca El Socorro Maracaturra
Review: A lovely example of the big-beaned Maracaturra variety: sweetly savory with notes of deep stone fruit and rich, sweet florals.
Coffee Origin: Palencia, Fraijanes Plateau growing region, central Guatemala

Name: Ethiopia Kochere Debo Washed Gellana
Review: An intricately classic expression of the great Yirgacheffe wet-processed type, lemony and floral with a fragrant sandalwood base.

Name: Guatemala Huehuetenango Miralvalle Washed
Review: Impressive medium-dark roasted Guatemala, pungently fruit-toned, briskly structured, sweetly floral.

Name: Ethiopia Gotiti Natural
Review: Flowers and fruit carry for miles in this natural-processed Ethiopia cup: clean, crisp, and chocolaty, too.

Name: Ethiopia Kayon Mountain Natural
Review: A deeply sweet natural-processed Ethiopia coffee with narcissus-like flowers and pungent, resiny myrrh as throughlines.
Coffee Origin: Odo Shakiso District, Guji Zone, Oromia Region, southern Ethiopia

Name: Colombia Jairo Alcaraz
Review: A rich-toned Colombia cup, deftly roasted to foreground chocolate and spice notes.

Name: Cream Tabby Espresso Blend
Review: A bright, intense espresso, fragrant and complex both in the straight shot and in milk.

Name: Esmeralda Estate Panama Geisha
Review: The startling complexity of the great Gesha variety is quietly but decisively expressed in a short, concentrated espresso shot produced from this Nespresso-compatible capsule.

Name: Brazil Cup of Excellence Prize Winner
Review: A sweet, delicately distinctive Brazil, cocoa- and floral-toned, a lesson in coffee grace. Best as a short, concentrated ristretto taken either straight or in short milk.
Coffee Origin: Chapada Diamantina growing region, Bahia State, Brazil

Name: Ethiopia Girma Eshetu
Review: A classic, on-point washed Ethiopia cup: floral-toned, with bright berry and zesty citrus notes, all enveloped in delicate cocoa.
Coffee Origin: Bita Genet District, Keffa Zone, southwestern Ethiopia

Name: Organic Dulce de Guatemala
Review: An intriguing Guatemala cup, classic yet idiosyncratic, redolent of stone fruit and sweet nuts, and an excellent value at $11.95 for 12 ounces.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Natural Grade 1
Review: A friendly, fruit-forward natural-process Ethiopia coffee with berry and floral notes alongside rich aromatic wood.

Name: Red Bourbon Honey Cold Brew Coffee
Review: An original cold-brew profile, sweet yet crisp, complexly fruit-toned, refreshing without loss of authority.

Name: Karimikui Espresso
Review: An intense Kenya espresso, confident and punchy, with deep floral, fruit and chocolate notes in both straight shot and milk.

Name: Colombia Finca La Ilusion Rosevel Ortiz Escarpeta Natural Espresso
Review: A fruit-driven natural-processed espresso from Colombia, particularly inviting in milk.
Coffee Origin: San Agust√≠n growing region, Huila Department, Colombia

Name: Guatemala Finca El Limonar Hugo Chavez Mendez
Review: A bright, crisp, cocoa-toned Guatemala coffee with a throughline of sweet herbs suggesting a fragrant lemon verbena.

Name: Colombia Finca La Loma Antonio Gualguan
Review: A crisp, sweet-toned Colombia cup with engaging stone fruit and chocolate notes throughout.

Name: Granja La Esperanza Tres Dragones Natural
Review: A fruit-forward natural-processed Colombia espresso, rich with chocolate and aromatic wood notes and an intriguing hint of brandy.
Coffee Origin: Valle del Cauca growing region, Colombia

Name: Costa Rica Tirra Natural
Review: A balanced, fruit-forward natural-processed Costa Rica cup, with a whisper of pleasing sweet ferment.

Name: El Salvador Loma La Gloria Natural
Review: An inviting natural-processed El Salvador coffee, sweetly tart in the straight shot and richly fruit- and cocoa-toned in milk.
Coffee Origin: El Boquer√≥n growing region, El Salvador

Name: Brazil Fazenda Sert√£ozinho
Review: A gently roast-toned natural-processed Brazil espresso that leads with notes of sweet nut and fruit, supported by an appealing cardamom-like spice. The nut and fruit turn distinctly chocolaty in milk.
Coffee Origin: S√£o Sebasti√£o da Grama, S√£o Paulo state, south-central Brazil

Name: Natural Sidamo Twakok G1
Review: This brisk natural-processed Ethiopia espresso presents a fruit note that‚Äôs a dead ringer for dried strawberries (supported by notes of lavender and sandalwood) and is especially attractive in cappuccino-scaled milk.
Coffee Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, south-central Ethiopia

Name: Costa Rica Cumbres Del Poas ‚ÄúPerla Negra‚Äù Natural
Review: A brightly expressed fruit and chocolate bomb with ballast from notes of rich nut and sweet flowers.
Coffee Origin: Sabanilla de Alajuela growing region, Costa Rica

Name: Ethiospro Blend
Review: An espresso blend trifecta that leads in equal parts with fruit, flowers and herbs (think black cherry, plumeria and spearmint, respectively).

Name: Ethiopia Gede Natural
Review: A crisp, clean natural-processed espresso from Ethiopia, as richly chocolate-toned in the straight shot as it is in milk.
Coffee Origin: Shakiso District, Guji Zone, southern Ethiopia

Name: Gesha Village Lot #25
Review: A strikingly original natural-processed Ethiopia Gesha, with high-toned floral notes, a suggestion of musky cannabis, and a complex, exhilarating presence in milk.
Coffee Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, south-central Ethiopia

Name: YCFCU Banko Gotiti Coop G1
Review: A natural-processed Ethiopia roasted for espresso that shimmers with an intricately layered range of sensation: sweet, savory, spice, floral, chocolate, fruit, expressed both in the straight shot and in milk.

Name: Yemen Haraaz
Review: A powerhouse espresso from this ancient origin, assertively fruit-toned and elegantly floral.

Name: Costa Rica Perla Negra
Review: A bold, lively, expressive natural-processed Costa Rica espresso, with suggestions of tropical fruit and chocolate fudge as the richly sweet throughlines.
Coffee Origin: Sabanilla de Alajuela growing region, Costa Rica

Name: Espresso 1849 Blend
Review: A complex, floral- and chocolate-driven espresso blend, as compelling in milk as in the straight shot.

Name: Ethiopia Deri Kochoha
Review: A good coffee choice for those who value softly stated brightness with delicate melony and floral aromatics.
Coffee Origin: West Guji Zone, Oromia Region, southern Ethiopia

Name: Guatemala Finca Las Terrazas
Review: A subtly original and pleasing Guatemala: sweet and honey-toned with a delicately brisk complement of aromatics.

Name: Suyusama Program Colombia
Review: A coffee with strong character situated on the intersection of sweet, tart and savory, with a crisp array of aromatics suggesting, in part, a fragrant potpourri of dried flowers.

Name: Static Peru Valle de Chingama Peru
Review: A fine Peru, with the round, pungently chocolaty character of the type supported by crisp floral top notes and a plump, smooth mouthfeel.

Name: Static Chirinos Peru
Review: A quietly rich Peru, sweet yet briskly zesty.

Name: Kenya Muranga Gondo
Review: A pretty Kenya cup with bright notes of stone fruit and spicy florals throughout, supported by an undercurrent of rich, aromatic myrrh.

Name: Costa Rica Esteban Zamora
Review: A classic wet-processed coffee from Costa Rica: crisp, balanced, sweetly herb-toned.

Name: El Salvador Loma La GLoria Natural
Review: A lively, bright, fruit-forward natural-processed coffee from a highly regarded producer in El Salvador.
Coffee Origin: El Boquer√≥n growing region, El Salvador

Name: Kenya
Review: A friendly Kenya cup that leads with crisp chocolate and deep floral notes, with a medium-dark roast profile that encourages a pleasing suggestion of smoky aromatic wood.

Name: Burundi Nkonge Hill Red Honey
Review: A tactfully medium-roasted coffee with caramel and date as sweet-toned ballast to notes of richly savory hop-like flowers.

Name: Ethiopia Kayon Mountain
Review: A richly sweet-tart, lively and complex Ethiopia coffee with deeply pleasing notes of mango and jasmine.
Coffee Origin: Odo Shakiso District, Guji Zone, southern Ethiopia

Name: Tano Batak Sumatra
Review: A multi-layered Sumatra cup with berry and tropical flowers as primary notes, balanced with fine pipe tobacco, sweet herbs and rich chocolate.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, North Sumatra Province, Indonesia

Name: Flight Espresso
Review: A compelling espresso blend with engaging sweet-tartness, rich aromatic wood notes, and delicately sweet floral tones redolent of lilac.

Name: Zambia AAA/AA
Review: A chocolaty and fruit-toned coffee from Zambia in south-central Africa, deftly roasted to medium-dark.

Name: Sumatra Batak Naga Saribu M-Plus
Review: A resonant, complexly expressed Sumatra. A hint of roasty pungency moves the chocolate forward and deepens the sweet-savory earth and tobacco notes.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, North Sumatra Province, Indonesia

Name: Ethiopia Guji Natural Dasaya G1
Review: A richly sweet, multi-layered natural-processed Ethiopia cup: berry- and cocoa-toned, with an inviting touch of sweet ferment, redolent of elderflower liqueur.
Coffee Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, south-central Ethiopia

Name: Dandelion Espresso Blend
Review: A complex, multi-layered espresso blend: floral and sweetly herbaceous in the straight shot; bittersweet and cocoa-toned in cappuccino-scaled milk.

Name: Choice Caramel Dried Prune
Review: A crisp, sweet-toned espresso blend: caramelly and fruit-toned, particularly floral in milk.

Name: Espresso Blend
Review: A chocolaty espresso blend with bright notes of stonefruit and deeply sweet floral tones. Especially appealing in milk.

Name: Reserve Cold Brew
Review: Deep, vibrant, elegant. In the right setting (summer dinner al fresco), this coffee would be a perfect match for grilled meat with a hint of smoke.

Name: Single Origin Ethiopia
Review: A superbly balanced, refreshing cold coffee, crisply cocoa-, citrus- and floral-toned.

Name: Cold Brew
Review: A balanced, classic coffee profile in cold-brew format. The sweet-tart brightness is roundly refreshing and nicely nuanced: sweet citrus, cocoa, flowers.

Name: Black House Blend Cold Brew
Review: A cleanly fruit-forward and refreshing cold coffee with a brisk structure and plush mouthfeel.

Name: Cold Brew
Review: Not a coffee purist‚Äôs cold brew, but a very engaging one: rich, syrupy and eccentric in its tequila-barrel nuance and odd yet pleasing overlap of salt, vanilla and chocolate.

Name: Baridi Black Cold Brew
Review: A confident, darker-roasted cold brew with a lean toward the savory, yet sweet-toned at its core.

Name: Cold Brew
Review: Crisp and bittersweet, with a complex, shifting set of flavor notes that layer and tease.

Name: F-Bomb
Review: Lively, bright, rich yet refreshing, saturated with deeply expressed fruit and chocolate notes.

Name: Cold Pressed Coffee
Review: A crisp, clean, refreshingly sweet-tart cold coffee with a citrus throughline.

Name: Cold Brew
Review: An easy-drinking, richly sweet cold-brew coffee, caramel- and nut-toned, with hints of lemon zest.

Name: Secret Beach Summer Blend
Review: Crisply invigorating, this cold coffee should please lovers of bone-dry white wines and hoppy ales.

Name: Taurus Earth Espresso
Review: A syrupy-bodied espresso with intriguing aromatics and a quiet presence in milk.

Name: Ethiopia Natural Yirgacheffe Adado Shara
Review: The ‚Äúnatural‚Äù or dried-in-the fruit processing develops an impressively light-footed yet cleanly lush version of the flowers, cocoa and fruit character of this fine Yirgacheffe.

Name: No. 7 Espresso Blend
Review: A roast-toned, sweet-savory espresso blend with rich floral and deep umami impulses.

Name: Kenya Embu Uteuzi Jimbo
Review: A deeply sweet Kenya with classic red fruit notes and added intrigue from tangy tamarind and a citrusy floral akin to lantana.

Name: Sumatra Batak Naga Saribu
Review: A complex, harmonious Sumatra cup, with sweetly tart fruit and deeply sweet floral notes enveloped in rich earthiness.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, North Sumatra Province, Indonesia

Name: Replay Espresso
Review: A great value for a richly sweet, floral and crisply citrusy espresso blend.

Name: Burundi Gaharo Hill Long Miles Coffee Project Natural
Review: A deeply sweet Burundi cup with a savory richness typical of Central Africa coffees and a throughline of pleasing herbaceousness.

Name: Kiniyota Burundi
Review: A richly sweet Burundi cup, with spicy floral tones and a savory note suggesting cumin; subtle and inviting.

Name: Burundi Gahahe Washing Station Microlot Honey
Review: A sweet, crisp, balanced Burundi cup, especially appealing in its quietly intriguing aromatics.

Name: Rwanda Cyato
Review: A richly sweet cup with the intrigue of savory herb notes throughout.

Name: Rwanda Hingakawa Women‚Äôs Co-op Fair Trade
Review: A citrusy, sweet-toned Rwanda cup with inviting notes of rich toffee.

Name: Uganda Kapchorwa
Review: A pleasingly bittersweet, spice-toned coffee from Uganda.

Name: Burundi Gitwe Natural Bourbon
Review: A balanced, clean natural-processed Burundi coffee with leading notes of stone fruit and citrus supported by rich aromatic wood tones.

Name: Gahahe Burundi Natural
Review: A natural-processed Burundi coffee that strikes a remarkable balance between lush fruit and spicy floral notes. It's also sweetly fermenty, and elegantly so.

Name: Winer
Review: An exhilaratingly high-toned Burundi with notes of stone fruit and spicy florals, enriched by cocoa tones throughout.

Name: Burundi Long Miles Coffee Project Natural
Review: A solid natural-processed Burundi coffee with crisp, clean fruit notes and a hint of cinnamon-like spice.

Name: Long Miles Coffee Project Nkonge Hill Burundi Red Honey
Review: A pleasingly rich Burundi, processed by the atypical red honey method. Sweetly fruit-forward yet elegantly clean.

Name: Tarime Tanzania
Review: An exquisitely balanced, multi-layered cup, rich with sweet fruit, herb and flower notes, deep and resonant throughout.

Name: DR Congo FTO Bourbon SOPACDI
Review: One of the finest Congos we've cupped in years: spice-toned, floral, tantalizingly sweet-savory, with a throughline of rich earth tones evoking a forest walk after a rain.
Coffee Origin: Kalehe, South Kivu Province, Democratic Republic of the Congo

Name: Mahonda Burundi
Review: A chocolaty Burundi coffee with richly crisp notes of dried mulberry and an especially appealing acidity, bright and juicy.

Name: Signature Hazelnut Dark Chocolate
Review: A lively espresso blend: chocolaty and floral-toned, especially in milk.

Name: Signature Floral Orange
Review: A subtly fruit-forward espresso blend, balanced by inviting chocolate suggestions and invigorating notes of citrus zest.

Name: El Salvador
Review: A classic Pacamara cup that finesses the sweet-savory paradox: simultaneous sweet fruit and floral impulses coupled with umami depth and intrigue.
Coffee Origin: Chalatenango growing region, northwest El Salvador

Name: Kiniyota Espresso
Review: A confident and expressive coffee from Burundi, roasted for espresso applications, with rich notes of stone fruit and dark chocolate enlivened by flowers suggesting spice-toned star jasmine.

Name: Guardian Spirit Espresso Blend
Review: An espresso blend with strong character, particularly expressed in the bittersweet, tart-leaning milk shot, deepened by notes of dark chocolate.

Name: Kenya Nyeri Rumukia Peaberry
Review: A rich, discreetly roast-toned Kenya cup, with notes of black currant and chocolate as throughlines.

Name: Kenya Nyeri Karuthi AA
Review: A pleasing, light-footed and accessible Kenya cup: crisp, citrusy, sweetly wood-framed.

Name: El Obraje Geisha
Review: An exciting Colombia Gesha cup that covers all the aromatic and gustatory bases: spicy florals notes, sweetly savory earth tones, umami sensations and rich sweetness throughout.

Name: Burundi
Review: A sweet-toned, approachable Burundi coffee, with inviting notes of vanilla and date at its heart.

Name: Mirador Colombia
Review: A sweetly tart, juicy Colombia cup animated by sweet floral and citrus notes throughout.

Name: Kenya Kirinyaga Mukangu AB
Review: A classic Kenya coffee with a rich balance of sweet and savory tones brightened by a crisp, juicy acidity.

Name: Brazil Carmo de Minas Natural
Review: A crisply fruit-toned, lightly fermenty natural-processed Brazil cup.
Coffee Origin: Carmo de Minas growing region, northeastern Minas Gerais State, Brazil

Name: Brazil Pulped Natural
Review: A deeply sweet pulped natural coffee with a throughline of spicy floral notes supported by cacao nib and buttery cashew.
Coffee Origin: Southern Minas Gerais State, southeastern Brazil

Name: Minas Gerais Isaias Ferreira No. 2
Review: A classic Brazil cup in its presentation of deeply sweet notes of dark chocolate, nut and raisiny fruit.
Coffee Origin: Southern Minas Gerais State, southeastern Brazil

Name: Brasil Ipanema Premier Cru Gold B69 Natural
Review: A graceful, light-footed cup, understated and refined.
Coffee Origin: Sul de Minas growing region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil

Name: Brazil Fazenda S√£o Bento
Review: A subtle but seductive cup, juicy, savory-sweet, with a pleasing range of aromatics: lavender, orange, cocoa.
Coffee Origin: Sul de Minas growing region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil

Name: Fazenda Recreio Bourbon Pulped Natural
Review: Gently but resonantly expressive and complex. For those who prefer subtle intricacy and depth to bold assertion.
Coffee Origin: Carmo de Minas growing region, northeastern Minas Gerais State, Brazil

Name: Brazil Ouro de Minas Pulped Natural
Review: A classic pulped-natural Brazil, delicate yet resonant, lightly floral, cedary, nut-toned.

Name: COE Brazil Naturals 2017 Sitio Esperanza 7th place
Review: A crisp, chocolate-toned Brazil natural cup, with inviting notes of dried hibiscus and vanilla-like florals.
Coffee Origin: Mantiqueira de Minas growing region, southern Minas Gerais State, Brazil

Name: Icamiabas Fazenda Klem Catua√≠ Natural
Review: A fruit-forward, natural-processed Brazil coffee that invokes a chocolate cordial with its predominant note of brandy-inflected dark chocolate.
Coffee Origin: Matas de Minas growing region, eastern Minas Gerais State, Brazil

Name: Brazil Chapada Diamantina Fazenda Floresta
Review: A confident chocolate- and floral-toned cup with a pleasingly bittersweet structure.
Coffee Origin: Chapada Diamantina growing region, Bahia State, Brazil

Name: Tumba Rwanda
Review: Lovely expression of the genius of Rwanda coffees: roundly sweet-savory in structure, resonant in aromatics, luxurious in mouthfeel.

Name: Mandheling Onan Ganjang
Review: A sweet yet umami-leaning Sumatra cup (think candy cap mushroom) with rich fruit and floral tones throughout.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, North Sumatra Province, Indonesia

Name: Burundi Nemba
Review: A floral- and spice-toned Burundi cup, simultaneously richly sweet and invitingly savory.

Name: Static Peru Cajamarca
Review: A delicately brisk, sweetly nut-toned variation on the classically gentle Peru profile.

Name: Ethiopia Banko Gotiti Natural
Review: A brightly sweet, crisply tart natural-processed Ethiopia cup: fruit- and floral-toned with a hint of intriguing cardamom-like spice.

Name: Espresso Blend
Review: A darker-roasted espresso in the robust traditional style, pungent with aromatic wood notes rounded and sweetened by dark chocolate suggestions.

Name: Flight Seasonal Espresso
Review: A brightly lively, complex yet coherent blend of both washed and natural-processed coffees: juicy, sweetly tart, chocolaty and floral-toned, with a hint of appealing sweet ferment.

Name: Yemen Microlot
Review: A stunningly balanced, bright, flavor-saturated Yemen cup characterized by rich fruit and cocoa-toned floral notes throughout.

Name: Lycello by Ninety Plus
Review: Complete: suave, flavor-saturated, big-bodied, sweetly and gracefully bright.

Name: Lotus by Ninety Plus
Review: For well-heeled coffee adventurers, a coffee so original it is difficult to categorize. It provokes a tremendous range of sensory association that situates it on the frontier of coffee expression, hovering somewhere between disturbing and extraordinary.

Name: Guji Allona Ethiopia Natural
Review: A classic natural-processed Ethiopia cup with clean berry notes, chocolate suggestions, and hints of sweetly spicy florals.
Coffee Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, south-central Ethiopia

Name: Monteverde Costa Rica
Review: A rich, chocolate- and raisin-toned Costa Rica cup, ideal for those who prefer a medium-dark roast.

Name: Kenya Nyeri Gatugi Peaberry
Review: A deftly darker-roasted coffee with notes of toasted coconut and savory almond alongside spicy florals: a pleasingly old-school presentation of the classic Kenya cup.

Name: Karen J Red Bourbon
Review: A complexly nuanced Kona-grown Red Bourbon, rife with sweet fruit and floral notes supported by undertones of rich sandalwood.
Coffee Origin: Holualoa, North Kona growing district, ‚ÄúBig Island‚Äù of Hawaii

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Koke
Review: An elegant natural-processed Yirgacheffe cup, complex with rich fruit and chocolate throughout.

Name: Ka‚Äôu Oro Yeast Typica
Review: Innovative practices during the ferment step of fruit removal appear to have encouraged intensified aromatic originality and depth in this traditional Big Island Typica. Floral, richly herb-toned, deeply sweet.
Coffee Origin: Ka'u growing region, Big Island of Hawaii

Name: Gedeb Yirgacheffe Ethiopia
Review: A dynamic Ethiopia cup with high-toned fruit notes and bittersweet florals, all enveloped in crisp cocoa.
Coffee Origin: Gedeb District, Gedeo Zone, southern Ethiopia

Name: Ethiopia Worka Natural
Review: A natural-processed Ethiopia cup with sweetly jammy fruit character, balanced by cocoa suggestions.

Name: Ecuador Pichincha Typica
Review: A nuanced Typica from Ecuador: balanced, quietly complex, richly sweet.

Name: Kenya Ndnunduri
Review: A spice-toned and fruit-laden Kenya cup, distinguished by perfumy, amber-like suggestions throughout.

Name: Ethiopia Gedeb Gotiti
Review: A crisp, high-toned Ethiopia coffee with rich fruit and sweet herb notes, next to deep evocations of honey.
Coffee Origin: Gedeb District, Gedeo Zone, southern Ethiopia

Name: Yemen Port of Mokha Al-Durrar
Review: A gorgeous Yemen coffee that rewards the observant drinker with layers of nuance that unfold with patience, touching all the notes: fruit, earth, chocolate, spice.

Name: Sumatra Tano Batak
Review: This paradoxical coffee offers both high tones and low: notes of juicy tropical fruit juxtaposed with rich pipe tobacco.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, North Sumatra Province, Indonesia

Name: Sumatra Tano Batak
Review: This rich Sumatra invokes the experience of eating cherries in a flower garden next to a patch of fresh, fragrant, just-turned earth.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, North Sumatra Province, Indonesia

Name: Kenya Gura AA
Review: A rich-toned Kenya cup with big, sweetly bright acidity and inviting notes of berry and coconut.

Name: Finca La Maria Geisha Natural
Review: A natural-processed Colombia Gesha that‚Äôs compelling in every way, with bright notes of stone fruit and honeysuckle in the cup, plump mouthfeel and flavor-saturated finish that lingers on and on.

Name: Ethiopia Guji Gigessa
Review: A juicy, bright Ethiopia cup with engaging fruit and floral notes and hints of rich aromatic wood, with a throughline of crisp, nut-like roasted cacao nib.
Coffee Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, south-central Ethiopia

Name: Granja La Esperanza Sudan Rume Natural
Review: An adventurer‚Äôs coffee from the get-go. In fact, especially at the get-go, when the odd, intense, sweet pungent sensation confronts us, then softens, opening up to a deep, layered intricacy.
Coffee Origin: Valle del Cauca growing region, Colombia

Name: Gedeb Espresso
Review: Fine wet-processed Ethiopia skillfully medium-roasted for presentation as espresso. Layered and pleasingly shifting aromatics persist throughout, from aroma through the milk shot.
Coffee Origin: Gedeb District, Yirgacheffe growing region, south-central Ethiopia

Name: Gaitania Espresso
Review: A tactful medium roast nicely develops crisp chocolate and subtle floral character in this intense, big-bodied single-origin espresso.

Name: Indonesia Flores Island
Review: A crisp Indonesia cup from the emerging Flores Island coffee growing region: delicate, with a throughline of tart fruit and sweet earth.

Name: Panama Baru Geisha Honey by Joseph
Review: An elegant, crisply sweet honey-processed Gesha cup with a throughline of pleasingly tart fruit notes enveloped in chocolate.

Name: Ethiopia Sidamo Shakiso Danbi Uddo Mulish Natural G1
Review: A delicate, flavor-saturated natural-processed Sidamo cup, animated by notes of raspberry and clove.
Coffee Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, south-central Ethiopia

Name: Panama Baru Geisha Natural by Joseph
Review: An understated and attractive natural-processed Gesha, rich with notes of sweet flowers, fruit-toned spices, and bright citrus zest.

Name: Static Indonesia Toarco Sulawesi
Review: A sweet, richly savory Sulawesi cup with a cocoa and mesquite throughline nuanced by butterscotch and fine musk.
Coffee Origin: Toraja growing region, south-central Sulawesi, Indonesia

Name: Burundi Buhorwa
Review: A deeply pleasing coffee from Burundi: rich, profoundly sweet throughout, and complexly layered with fruit, floral and aromatic wood notes.

Name: Warrior in the Forest Blend
Review: An Ethiopia-Indonesia blend that offers both high-toned sweetness and warm, low-toned spice notes reminiscent of clove.

Name: Dodora Double
Review: An exceptional, vivacious Ethiopia coffee in which high-toned floral notes, sweetly tart fruits, and rich chocolate tones harmonize.
Coffee Origin: Gedeo Zone, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern EthiopiaGedeo Zone, southern Ethiopia

Name: Poas Red Honey
Review: A honey-processed Costa Rica cup expressing equal parts sweet and tart: think candied apple and pomegranate wrapped in rich, creamy cashew butter.
Coffee Origin: Sabanilla de Alajuela, Central Valley, Costa Rica

Name: Lekali (Nepal)
Review: The first coffee from Nepal ever rated by Coffee Review, and well worth seeking out for its confident savory-sweet cup.

Name: Costa Rica Tarrazu
Review: A paradoxical natural-processed Costa Rica coffee with big sweetness (fruit and florals) and rich aromatic wood notes in equal measure.

Name: Decaf Espresso
Review: An inviting decaffeinated espresso laden with notes of dark chocolate and sweet florals. Particularly appealing in cappuccino-scaled milk.

Name: Summer Night Blend Espresso
Review: A lush, floral and richly sweet espresso blend, with dark chocolate tones as the throughline.

Name: Ethiopia Reko
Review: A classic Ethiopia cup: balanced, bright and deeply sweet, with notes of berry and stone fruit.

Name: Sumatra Tano Batak
Review: A classic Sumatra that displays its clean, fresh-earth character and grapefruity pungency without apology, supported by crisp chocolate, vanilla bean and pear.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, North Sumatra Province, Indonesia

Name: Kenya Kirinyaga
Review: A complex, richly layered, juicy-sweet Kenya cup.

Name: Ethiopia
Review: A confident, juicy-rich Ethiopia with appealing notes of citrus and cherry.
Coffee Origin: Sidama (also Sidamo) growing region, south-central Ethiopia

Name: Ethiopia Guji Deri Korcha White Honey
Review: An impressive white-honey processed coffee‚Äîrichly fruit- and floral-toned.
Coffee Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, south-central Ethiopia

Name: Nicaragua Finca Libre
Review: A determined sweetness and plump mouthfeel round and harmonize tart citrus and crisp cedar and nut notes.

Name: Congo Kivu
Review: Inviting notes of chocolate and tea rose carry this resonant, sweetly tart, slightly darker-roasted coffee from central Africa.
Coffee Origin: Kahale, South Kivu Province, Democratic Republic of the Congo

Name: Three Queens Blend
Review: Exceptional, versatile cup. Satisfies with its balance, yet surprises with its lush, layered intricacy. Blending at its most committed and original.

Name: Sumatra Mutu Batak
Review: A fine Sumatra, simultaneously expressing the pungent, full, resonantly earthy genius of the type, while lifting it with refreshing lightness and complex vivacity.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, North Sumatra Province, Indonesia

Name: Rwanda Bufcafe Remera
Review: A fine expression of the classic Rwanda and Central Africa cup, vibrantly and roundly bright, yet crucially deepened and nuanced by drier and more savory suggestions of lemon verbena and cooked root vegetables.

Name: Kiniyota Burundi
Review: One of the more impressive Burundis we‚Äôve tested in some years: roundly sweet-toned and bright, crucially supported by a deep savory resonance.

Name: Sumatra Mandheling
Review: A deeply sweet, earth-toned Sumatra cup, with enveloping notes of pipe tobacco and rich nut butter.
Coffee Origin: Mandheling growing region, northern Sumatra, Indonesia

Name: Kona Mocca¬Æ
Review: An out-of-the-ordinary coffee but a superbly balanced and complete one, with particularly seductive floral and chocolate notes.
Coffee Origin: Holualoa, North Kona growing district, ‚ÄúBig Island‚Äù of Hawaii

Name: Ethiopia Suke Quto Honey
Review: This honey-processed Ethiopia is a citrus and berry chorus, from lime blossom in the aroma to raspberry jam in the cup, backed by continuous suggestions of sandalwood and crisp cacao nib.
Coffee Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, south-central Ethiopia

Name: Firebird Espresso
Review: An evocative, richly sweet espresso blend centered on deep chocolate with rich floral and bright citrus undertones.

Name: Ethiopia Dumerso Light Roast
Review: A balanced yet intricate dried-in-the-fruit Yirgacheffe, flowers grounded in chocolate with a whiff of brandy.

Name: Kenya AA Karamundi
Review: A cocoa-toned Kenya cup with notes of stone fruit and sweet florals and the added intrigue of a tart, tamarind-like edge.

Name: Finca San Luis Colombia Espresso
Review: A quietly zesty straight shot nicely rounded and deepened with chocolate and nut. All carry nicely into cappuccino-scaled milk.

Name: Ethiopia Biftu Gundina Coop Espresso
Review: A fine darker roasted espresso: The scorched wood notes are lively and aromatic, the chocolate pleasingly bittersweet; hints of zesty citrus and sweet flowers maintain vivacity.
Coffee Origin: Agaro District, Jimma Zone, west-central Ethiopia

Name: Ethiopia Natural Sidamo Papilio
Review: An unusual and engaging natural-processed Ethiopia: crisp, sweet-savory, complex and original in its cocoa, lemon-herb and grappa-toned aromatics.
Coffee Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, south-central Ethiopia

Name: Thai Single-Origin Natural-Processed Espresso
Review: An accessible natural-processed espresso from Thailand, fruit-toned with a chocolate foundation.

Name: Ethiopia Banko Gotiti Natural
Review: A perfumy, floral- and spice-toned natural-processed Ethiopia cup with an especially juicy acidity.

Name: Peru Finca Ecol√≥gica Agua Colorada
Review: A solid Peru cup: rich, deeply sweet, with the intrigue of a perfumy musk-like note throughout.

Name: Love Letters
Review: A harmonious melding of sweet floral and fruit notes from the El Salvador component of the blend and a more tobacco-toned sweetness from the Indonesia contribution.
